hi, i'm making a multi-agent sim thingy where i'm hoping to evolve agents 
that can play tag -- although i seem to remember seeing a paper about this 
somewhere, but i'm enjoying doing it on my own.

the basic idea is to have a finite size area, agents with 
position/velocity, and at any one time, an "it" - which can change if the 
current It touches another. I figure that this would be an interesting 
thing to learn, since when an agent is not It they will be trying to run 
away from It, and when they are It they will try to run towards another 
agent. i want to use competitive co-evolution and NN controllers 
(eventually using neat, although i'm using a simple crossover+mutation GA 
with binary tournament selection right now). fitness is the average 
distance from the target over a certain number of time steps.

my first task was just for agents to follow around a moving target, where 
their input is a bearing to the target and their outputs is a change to 
their current x and y velocities - this is basically evolving sin and 
cosine in the network. with a population size of 10, with 5 new offspring 
each turn, it readily solves this problem within a couple hundred 
generations. even though ive done all sorts of evolutionary algorithms, 
its still DAMN cool to see the little dots start out moving randomly and 
then over time start swarming around the target ... hehe this stuff is so 
cool. anyway, i then changed their output to be their new heading and 
velocity, and they also learn how to follow the target fairly easily, 
although now that i think about it since one of the inputs is the bearing 
they pretty much just need to learn to turn to the bearing.

anyway, my question is this: what do you use as inputs for something 
like the tag 
problem? i mean 
i guess 
technically i could have an input which gives the bearing for each other 
agent and then a binary input whether or not they are It. i don't really 
like this, though, because you have to change the number of inputs based 
on the current number of agents in the simulation. other ideas ive had 
were to divide the circle around the agent into a discrete number of arcs 
and then flag the inputs that have something in their field of vision ... 
has anyone tried anything with that kind of thing?
